items.title: People submit Welsh placenames to project to protect linguistic heritage
items.content_html:
Entries include Welsh language names for fields and hills in move to ensure preservation of stories and legends

Dozens of placenames in Welsh, some hinting at ancient legends, others telling rich stories of how people used to live, have been submitted to a project designed to make sure they are preserved.

The Welsh government appealed for people to add historical names that may be missing from online maps so they could be saved for future generations. Within two weeks, about 200 submissions were received, including local Welsh language names for fields, hills and areas.

D√¥l y Tylwyth Teg (Fairy Folk Meadow/Fairies‚Äô Meadow) in Aberfan, south Wales. The person who sent the suggestion said the field was known by the Welsh name by people who spoke Cymraeg, the Welsh language. A nearby school that teaches through Welsh refers to the field by this name and uses it for events.

Caeau Maelorddin (Fields of Maelor City) near Aberystwyth, west Wales, are a collection of fields near Tanybwlch beach. The contributor said his late grandfather recalled many people referring to a group of now individually named fields as Caeau Maelorddin. They were close to Pen Dinas, the hill where the giant Maelor Gawr was said to live.

Ffynnon Glog (Rock Well) near Rhyd, in Gwynedd, north Wales, is a hidden well in a roadside bank, according to the contributor. The water in the well was once used as a remedy for ailments and takes its name from Y Glog, a prominent rocky outcrop nearby.

Continue reading...

items.title: Inside the Republican network behind big soda‚Äôs bid to pit Maga against Maha
items.content_html:
A Guardian investigation finds the US soda and snack-food industries, threatened by RFK Jr‚Äôs movement to change Americans‚Äô eating habits, have turned to a group of well-connected strategists, shadowy pollsters and ‚Äòanti-woke‚Äô influencers

Major US soft-drink and snack-food corporations are waging a coordinated campaign that aims to pit Donald Trump‚Äôs Maga faithful against Robert F Kennedy Jr‚Äôs Make America Healthy Again movement, a Guardian investigation in partnership with environmental watchdog Fieldnotes has found. Their goal is to stymie the Maha-led effort to curb Americans‚Äô consumption of soda and ultra-processed foods.

To carry out the plan, the companies have turned to a partially formalized network of for-hire pollsters, strategists and political financiers with deep ties to the national Republican party ‚Äì several of whom have taken steps that obscure their connection to the effort and to one another. In the process, the industry has also been aided less directly by a loose coalition of free-market ideologues who have previously worked to advance Trump‚Äôs deregulatory agenda.

Asked about the hundreds of Palestinians from Gaza approved for visas in Australia and whether the ceasefire changes anything, Tony Burke said he‚Äôs not sure all of those approved for visas are still alive.

He says some will choose to stay in Australia, and others may end up with other options they might take up.

And there will be some people who we don‚Äôt hear from again. And there‚Äôs some on that case list that we haven‚Äôt heard from for a very long time. A significant number of them are part of split family groups, where some of the family is, in fact, here in Australia and they‚Äôre wanting to join.

You need to remember, our humanitarian program that we run around the world isn‚Äôt limited to places where there‚Äôs an active war. There is decency that Australia shows to people from around the world ‚Ä¶ there are Israelis who have been approved for humanitarian visas as well. I‚Äôve got no intention of cancelling those either. We‚Äôre a decent country. We are talking about people where all the checks have been made. And some of them won‚Äôt choose to come here, some of them won‚Äôt be alive any more ‚Ä¶

Probably the most significant change in response these days is the majority of people now get sent straight back to their country of origin. So, you used to really only see people going back to Indonesia or off to Nauru for processing. But the majority of cases now are going straight back to country of origin.

We had one very recently where, within 72 hours, we had everybody back to their country of origin. There was one in May, for example, where it was a mixed boatload of people from different countries and we had to, you know, from three different sorts of citizenships that people had come from. It was more complex but we still made sure we returned people directly straight back to the countries of origin.

items.content_html:

A chemical linked to impaired sexual development, obesity and cancer has been found in baby dummies manufactured by three big European brands.

Dummies made by the Dutch multinational Philips, the Swiss oral health specialists Curaprox and the French toy brand Sophie la Girafe were found to contain bisphenol A (BPA), according to laboratory testing by dTest, a Czech consumer organisation. Philips said they had carried out subsequent testing and found no BPA, while Sophie la Girafe said the amount found was insignificant.

items.title: Weather tracker: Japanese islands struck by two successive typhoons
items.content_html:
Typhoon Nakri sweeps through Izu Islands off Tokyo, a week after Halong, causing damage and disruption

The Izu Islands in Japan have endured another powerful blow as Typhoon Nakri swept through on Monday, following in the footsteps of Typhoon Halong, which struck a week earlier.

Officials on Hachijojima Island, south of Tokyo, reported disruption and damage to about 220 homes after the storm brought 37mm (1.5in) of rain in one hour and gusts of up to 95mph (152km/h). Airport operations were disrupted, infrastructure damaged, and heavy rainfall caused landslides across the island chain. The typhoon also generated 9-metre waves, creating dangerous coastal conditions. Off the Pacific coast in Oiso, in Kanagawa prefecture, three men were swept away while fishing, one of whom has been confirmed dead.

items.title: ‚ÄòYour basis to live is checked at each and every step‚Äô: India‚Äôs ID system divides opinion
items.content_html:
Keir Starmer is considering Aadhaar as model for UK, but detractors warn of ‚Äòdigital coercion‚Äô and security breaches

It is often difficult for people in India to remember life before Aadhaar. The digital biometric ID, allegedly available for every Indian citizen, was only introduced 15 years ago but its presence in daily life is ubiquitous.

Indians now need an Aadhaar number to buy a house, get a job, open a bank account, pay their tax, receive benefits, buy a car, get a sim card, book priority train tickets and admit children into school. Babies can be given Aadhaar numbers almost immediately after they are born. While it is not mandatory, not having Aadhaar de facto means the state does not recognise you exist, digital rights activists say.

items.content_html: Political deadlock, huge debts and another of President Macron's appointed heads of government has resigned. Concerns are growing in Berlin about the future of Franco-German relations.

items.title: Germany investigating Temu on price-fixing suspicions
items.content_html: Germany's competition watchdog has announced an investigation of Chinese discount online retail site temu.com, suspecting it of influencing retailers' prices. The site is the fastest-growing of its kind in the world.

items.title: Will the 2026 World Cup be a disaster for fans?
items.content_html: The 2026 FIFA World Cup is set to be the most expensive, polluting and political yet.

items.title: Plant-based 'burger' label grilled in EU parliament
items.content_html: Can a veggie schnitzel legally be called a schnitzel even if it contains no meat? Some have argued such names are confusing consumers. The European Parliament seems to agree.

items.title: Anti-immigration politics contribute to racism in Germany
items.content_html: Far-right gains, economic stagnation and increased political focus on migration can be major drivers of racial discrimination in European countries such as Germany.

items.title: What the 'One Piece' pirate flag symbolizes for Gen Z protestors
items.content_html: How did a flag from the Japanese anime series "One Piece" become a rallying symbol for Gen Z protest movements around the world?

items.title: EU to double steel tariffs amid influx of Chinese imports
items.content_html: The EU's industry chief says the bloc plans to raise tariffs on foreign steel in a bid to counter cheap Chinese imports. Nearly 100,000 jobs have been lost in the European steel sector in the past 15 years.

items.title: Malaysian football to dispute FIFA 'cheating' allegations
items.content_html: Malaysia found seven new ringers for a 4-0 win against Vietnam. But FIFA says it was too good to be true, alleging "cheating," because none had the Malaysian-born grandparent they would need to play for the country.

items.title: Olympic champion Caster Semenya: 'It's never the end'
items.content_html: Speaking to DW, the South African runner vows to continue her fight against sex eligibility rules and calls out 'weak leadership' from World Athletics.

items.title: Renewables overtake coal in global electricity generation
items.content_html: In the first half of 2025, more electricity was generated from green sources than from coal. Solar and wind capacities are growing at a faster pace than global electricity demand, according to new research.

items.title: German Chancellor questions voluntary military service plan
items.content_html: Voluntary military service or a return to conscription? The dispute over this issue seemed to have been settled within the German government. Now, criticism is flaring up, fueled by Chancellor Friedrich Merz.

items.title: Could France's political turmoil spark eurozone debt crisis?
items.content_html: The collapse of yet another French government for its inability to push austerity measures through parliament is raising fears that the debt of the European Union's second-largest economy is spinning out of control.

items.title: Oct. 7 Israeli music festival featured in Berlin exhibition
items.content_html: Hamas's October 7, 2023, terror attack on the Nova Music Festival is remembered in a Berlin installation of an art show that has toured major cities worldwide.

items.title: Life in Germany since October 7, 2023, and the Gaza war
items.content_html: Two years have passed since the Hamas-led attack in Israel. How has life in Germany changed since then ‚Äî for Jews, Palestinians and the country as a whole?

items.title: Germany news: Merz says Putin waging 'hybrid war'
items.content_html: Chancellor Friedrich Merz has said Russia's president is trying to "intimidate and instill fear" and is waging an "information war" against Germany. Meanwhile, electric cars are set to get a tax break. More on DW.

items.title: Gold tops $4,000 as demand for safe assets rises
items.content_html: Gold and bitcoin have both hit record highs in recent days. Geopolitical and economic uncertainty are factors, while doubts over the US dollar are attracting institutional investors.

items.title: Football: Sara D√§britz retires from Germany national team
items.content_html: Sara D√§britz, one of Germany's most experienced players, will no longer play for the national team. She follows former teammates Alexandra Popp and Svenja Huth in calling time on her international career.

items.title: Lee Miller: From surrealist muse to war photographer
items.content_html: A chronicler of the 20th century, from her surrealist experiments with Man Ray to gripping photos from World War II, Lee Miller put her unique stamp on all of her work, as shown at the Tate Britain.

items.title: What to know about the 2025-26 Women's Champions League
items.content_html: The new Champions League season is here with a new format, new rising stars and a big challenge for Bayern Munich.

items.title: Israeli and Palestinian films face distribution obstacles
items.content_html: Two years into the war in Gaza between Hamas and Israel, filmmakers who examine the conflict in their works have struggled to find distribution. The Israeli government has also worked to silence critical voices.

items.title: Women's football: What escalating transfer records mean
items.content_html: The women's football transfer record was broken four times in two months this year and has risen almost 600% since 2019. It reflects a growing commercial relevance but poses issues for some, including the Bundesliga.

items.title: Can the US achieve cervical cancer herd immunity?
items.content_html: The human papillomavirus (HPV) is responsible for at least 95% of the 660,000 cervical cancer diagnoses globally. But US research shows the tremendous impact of ongoing vaccine programs.

items.title: Nobel Prize: 7 facts we bet you didn't know
items.content_html: Did you know Einstein's relativity theory was rejected? That prize medals get auctioned off for millions? Or that prized discoveries were later retracted? These Nobel facts will amaze you.

items.title: Are Volkswagen's EVs made with African conflict minerals?
items.content_html: The German carmaker requires substantial amounts of minerals for its transition to electric vehicles. But new research by DW shows that some of Africa's most notorious smelters are part of Volkswagen's supply chain.

items.title: Is the Nobel Prize still relevant today?
items.content_html: The Nobel Prize is considered the "Mount Everest of science." But it faces criticism over how winners are chosen, and may give a warped idea of scientific progress.

items.title: Online attacks threaten major climate-friendly diet report
items.content_html: A major scientific update to one of the most influential food and planetary health reports of the past decade is in the crosshairs of a pro-meat misinformation campaign.

items.title: German Unity Day explained
items.content_html: October 3 is a public holiday all over Germany commemorating the reunification of the once divided nation. But why was Germany divided in the first place? And when was it reunited? DW has the answers.

items.title: Chess: Germany's men surging but India the benchmark
items.content_html: Germany's men head to the European Team Championship of chess in Georgia with the wind in their sails. A rising star and a surprise late bloomer offer the European country hope but India remain a powerhouse.

items.title: 35 years after Berlin Wall, East German football struggling
items.content_html: East Germany's political collapse was mirrored in football, but a focus on youth brings hope for the future.

items.title: EA: What do Saudi Arabia and US get from video game deal?
items.content_html: A consortium led by Saudi Arabia and a key figure in Donald Trump's circle have brokered a big money deal for video game publisher Electronic Arts. It looks to be something bigger than pure business.

items.title: Pilot crisis looms as airlines scramble to fill cockpits
items.content_html: Many airlines worldwide are struggling to fill their cockpits with experienced pilots as demand for air travel grows. Can signing bonuses and fast-track promotions make up for a massive retirement wave?

items.title: Berlin to crack down on a beloved giveaway tradition
items.content_html: One resident's trash is another's treasure has long been part of Berlin's culture, but the German capital has had enough and plans to raise fines. Will they work?

items.title: Conservationist Jane Goodall: 'The biggest problem is greed'
items.content_html: A tireless advocate for conservation and one of the world's most prominent primatologists, Jane Goodall has passed away at 91. In 2019, she spoke with DW about why it's important to protect our environment and wildlife.

items.title: Older film and TV actors who retain star power
items.content_html: Populations around the world are aging fast. But, from Steve Martin to Helen Mirren, leading older actors are showing how seniors can have a starring role in healthy and diverse societies.

items.title: 'Chunk' wins Fat Bear Week 2025 award in Alaska
items.content_html: The bulky brown bear from Alaska won the online competition by more than 30,000 votes despite a broken jaw impeding his pre-hibernation gorging. Voters also apparently forgave and forgot last year's infanticide.

items.title: Oktoberfest overcrowding sparks safety concerns
items.content_html: Munich's Oktoberfest attracts millions of visitors. The festival entrances were briefly closed over the weekend due to overcrowding.

items.title: How a gloomy German loaf of bread went viral in the US
items.content_html: Bernd the Bread has been an icon of German children's TV for 25 years. After a TV appearance on John Oliver's show, he's now gained new fans.

items.title: Environmental damage threatens prosperity in Europe
items.content_html: Despite progress in climate change action, Europe's environment is being seriously degraded, according to a new report. Researchers say environmental damage threatens competitiveness and quality of life on the continent.

items.title: Nvidia chips in millions for AI factory in Armenia
items.content_html: As costly artificial intelligence data centers get built in rich countries, there's concern that many countries will be left behind. But Armenia is poised to get a boost from Nvidia's plans for a $500 million AI factory.

items.title: Eurovision to vote on whether Israel can participate in 2026
items.content_html: The European Broadcasting Union will have its members vote on Israel's participation after calls to exclude the country over the war in Gaza.

items.title: H3N2 influenza spreads rapidly in Delhi, northern India
items.content_html: An aggressive flu virus has gripped northern India. Two-thirds of families in the region are affected. Who's most at risk? And how can people protect themselves?

items.title: Chimps regularly consume alcohol, study finds
items.content_html: A new study has observed that chimpanzees regularly eat fermented fruit together, suggesting that alcohol consumption is more deeply rooted in human evolution than previously thought.

items.title: Trump tariffs: Who stands to lose most from new US pharma duties?
items.content_html: The US president's latest tariff move will see the US impose 100% levies on imports of branded or patented pharmaceutical goods from October 1. What could it mean for global trade?

items.title: Trump's autism call: What the Tylenol science really says
items.content_html: Donald Trump advised pregnant women not to take Tylenol amid announcing a set of new autism policies. Health experts are concerned. What do the studies cited by the White House actually say?

items.title: How Russia's mounting economic woes could force Putin's hand
items.content_html: The Russian economy is in trouble. Growth has stalled, energy revenues have plunged, and the budget deficit is growing. If the EU and US step up sanctions, things could get more serious still.

items.title: Nations deliver new climate targets ahead of climate summit
items.content_html: With just weeks to go until the international climate conference, nations are stepping up to submit new climate targets for 2035. But will they be enough to prevent a climate catastrophe?

items.title: State of climate change: How healthy is our planet?
items.content_html: Scientists say we've already exceeded seven of nine planetary boundaries contributing to Earth's stability, life support and resilience. This poses a risk, but it's not all bad news.

items.title: Germany's bid to lead in autonomous driving faces roadblocks
items.content_html: Germany has the research expertise, a car production ecosystem and even test tracks for autonomous driving. But Europe's biggest auto nation still lags when it comes to putting self-driving cars on the road.

items.title: US vaccine, painkiller stances concern global health experts
items.content_html: When the US speaks, the world listens when it comes to health policy. Experts say the Trump administration's changes to vaccine and medicine recommendations in the US could undermine health messaging worldwide.

items.title: How Donald Trump's H-1B visa fee could affect the US economy
items.content_html: Critics say the president's plan to charge $100,000 application fees for the H-1B visa program will greatly stifle the US economy. Universities, nonprofits and tech startups stand to be most affected.

items.title: Here's how flowers can harvest vital metals
items.content_html: As demand for nickel grows, plants could help suck out vital raw materials from soil. Could this replace conventional mining that's harmful to the environment?

items.title: Why science doesn't support Trump's Tylenol link to autism
items.content_html: Donald Trump claims to have the "answer to autism." On Monday, the US president claimed that a popular painkiller increases the risk of autism. Researchers say it doesn't work like that.

items.title: Welcome to 2050: Could Berlin's future look like this?
items.content_html: If Berlin were to become a climate-neutral city within the next 25 years, daily life could be radically different.

items.title: Is the birth control pill destroying women's sex drive?
items.content_html: Decreased libido isn't listed on most birth control pill information leaflets. Yet, research shows it can affect libido ‚Äî just not for everyone.

items.title: Mapping the world's oceans ‚Äî a blessing or a curse?
items.content_html: Oceans cover three-quarters of the Earth, yet only 20% of the seafloor has yet been mapped. The race to understand these depths could further scientific understanding, but also lead to exploitation.

items.title: Could Chinese AI threaten Western submarines?
items.content_html: A new Chinese AI system is said to detect even the most modern submarines. Is it a real threat to maritime security or just a bluff?
